The Morning fresh, dappling her horse with roses,</br>(Vext at the lingring shades, that long had left her</br>In Tithons freezing arms) the light discloses;</br>And chasing Night, of rule and heav'n bereft her:</br>The Sunne with gentle beams his rage disguises,</br>And like aspiring tyrants, temporises;</br>Never to be endur'd, but when he falls, or rises.

Thirsil from withy prison, as he uses,</br>Lets out his flock, and on an hill stood heeding</br>Which bites the grasse, and which his meat refuses;</br>So his glad eyes fed with their greedy feeding:</br>Straight flock a shoal of Nymphs and shepherd-swains</br>While all their lambes rang'd on the flowry plains;</br>Then thus the boy began, crown'd with their circling trains.

You gentle shepherds, and you snowie fires,</br>That sit around, my rugged rimes attending;</br>How may I hope to quit your strong desires,</br>In verse uncomb'd such wonders comprehending?</br>Too well I know my rudenesse all unfit</br>To frame this curious Isle, whose framing yet</br>Was never throughly known to any humane wit.

Thou Shepherd-God, who onely know'st it right,</br>And hid'st that art from all the world beside;</br>Shed in my mistie breast thy sparkling light,</br>And in this fogge my erring footsteps guide;</br>Thou who first mad'st, and never wilt forsake it:</br>Else how shall my weak hand dare undertake it,</br>When thou thy self ask'st counsel of thy self to make it?

Next to Koilia, on the right side stands,</br>Fairly dispread in large dominion,</br>Th' Arch-citie Hepar, stretching her commands</br>To all within this lower region;</br>Fenc't with sure barres, and strongest situation;</br>So never fearing foreiners invasion:</br>Hence are the walls slight, thinne; built but for sight and fashion.

To th' Heart and to th' Head-citie surely ti'd</br>With firmest league, and mutuall reference:</br>His liegers there, theirs ever here abide,</br>To take up strife, and casuall difference:</br>Built all alike, seeming like rubies sheen,</br>Of some peculiar matter; such I ween,</br>As over all the world may no where else be seen.

Much like a mount it easily ascendeth;</br>The upper part's all smooth as slipperie glasse:</br>But on the lower many a cragge dependeth;</br>Like to the hangings of some rockie masse:</br>Here first the purple fountain making vent,</br>By thousand rivers through the Isle dispent,</br>Gives every part fit growth and daily nourishment.

In this fair town the Isles great Steward dwells;</br>His porphyre house glitters in purple die;</br>In purple clad himself:  from hence he deals</br>His store to all the Isles necessitie:</br>And though the rent he daily duly pay,</br>Yet doth his flowing substance ne're decay;</br>All day he rent receives, returns it all the day.

And like that golden starre, which cuts his way</br>Through Saturns ice, and Mars his firy ball;</br>Temp'ring their strife with his more kindely ray:</br>So 'tween the Splenions frost and th' angry Gall</br>The joviall Hepar sits; with great expence</br>Cheering the Isle by his sweet influence;</br>So slakes their envious rage and endlesse difference.

Within, some say, Love hath his habitation;</br>Not Cupids self, but Cupids better brother:</br>For Cupids self dwells with a lower nation,</br>But this more sure, much chaster then the other;</br>By whose command we either love our kinde,</br>Or with most perfect love affect the minde;</br>With such a diamond knot he often souls can binde.

Two purple streams here raise their boiling heads;</br>The first and least in th' hollow cavern breeding,</br>His waves on divers neighbour grounds dispreads:</br>The next fair river all the rest exceeding,</br>Topping the hill, breaks forth in fierce evasion,</br>And sheds abroad his Nile-like inundation;</br>So gives to all the Isle their food and vegetation.

Yet these from other streams much different;</br>For others, as they longer, broader grow;</br>These as they runne in narrow banks impent,</br>Are then at least, when in the main they flow:</br>Much like a tree, which all his roots so guides,</br>That all the trunk in his full body hides;</br>Which straight his stemme to thousand branches subdivides.

Yet lest these streams might hap to be infected</br>With other liquours in the well abounding;</br>Before their flowing chanels are detected,</br>Some lesser delfs, the fountains bottome sounding,</br>Suck out the baser streams, the springs annoying,</br>An hundred pipes unto that end employing;</br>Thence run to fitter place their noisome load convoying.

Such is fair Hepar; which with great dissension</br>Of all the rest pleads most antiquitie;</br>But yet th' Heart-citie with no lesse contention,</br>And justest challenge, claims prioritie:</br>But sure the Hepar was the elder bore;</br>For that small river, call'd the Nurse, of yore</br>Laid boths foundation, yet Hepar built afore.

Three pois'nous liquours from this purple well</br>Rise with the native streams; the first like fire,</br>All flaming hot, red, furious, and fell,</br>The spring of dire debate, and civile ire;</br>Which wer't not surely held with strong retention,</br>Would stirre domestick strife, and fierce contention,</br>And waste the weary Isle with never ceas'd dissension.

Therefore close by a little conduit stands,</br>Choledochus, that drags this poison hence,</br>And safely locks it up in prison bands;</br>Thence gently drains it through a narrow fence;</br>A needfull fence, attended with a guard,</br>That watches in the straits all closely barr'd,</br>Lest some might back escape, and break the prison ward.

The next ill stream the wholesome fount offending,</br>All dreery black and frightfull, hence convay'd</br>By divers drains unto the Splenion tending,</br>The Splenion o're against the Hepar laid,</br>Built long, and square:  some say that laughter here</br>Keeps residence; but laughter fits not there,</br>Where darknesse ever dwells, and melancholy fear.

And should these waies, stopt by ill accident,</br>To th' Hepar streams turn back their muddie humours;</br>The cloudie Isle with hellish dreeriment</br>Would soon be fill'd, and thousand fearfull rumours:</br>Fear hides him here, lockt deep in earthy cell;</br>Dark, dolefull, deadly-dull, a little hell;</br>Where with him fright, despair, and thousand horrours dwell.

If this black town in over-growth increases,</br>With too much strength his neighbours over-bearing;</br>The Hepar daily, and whole Isle decreases,</br>Like ghastly shade, or ashie ghost appearing:</br>But when it pines, th' Isle thrives; its curse, his blessing:</br>So when a tyrant raves, his subjects pressing,</br>His gaining is their losse, his treasure their distressing.

The third bad water, bubbling from this fountain,</br>Is wheyish cold, which with good liquours meint,</br>Is drawn into the double Nephros mountain;</br>Which suck the best for growth, and nourishment:</br>The worst, as through a little pap, distilling</br>To divers pipes, the pale cold humour swilling,</br>Runs down to th' Urine-lake, his banks thrice daily filling.

These mountains differ but in situation;</br>In form and matter like:  the left is higher,</br>Lest even height might slack their operation:</br>Both like the Moon which now wants half her fire;</br>Yet into two obtuser angles bended,</br>Both strongly with a double wall defended;</br>And both have walls of mudde before those walls extended.

The sixt and last town in this region,</br>With largest stretcht precincts, and compasse wide,</br>Is that, where Venus and her wanton sonne</br>(Her wanton Cupid) will in youth reside:</br>For though his arrows and his golden bow</br>On other hills he frankly does bestow,</br>Yet here he hides the fire with which each heart doth glow.

For that great Providence, their course foreseeing</br>Too eas'ly led into the sea of death;</br>After this first, gave them a second being,</br>Which in their off-spring newly flourisheth:</br>He therefore made the fire of generation</br>To burn in Venus courts without cessation,</br>Out of whose ashes comes another Island nation.

For from the first a fellow Isle he fram'd,</br>(For what alone can live, or fruitfull be?)</br>Arren the first, the second Thelu nam'd;</br>Weaker the last, yet fairer much to see:</br>Alike in all the rest, here disagreeing,</br>Where Venus and her wanton have their being:</br>For nothing is produc't of two in all agreeing.

But though some few in these hid parts would see</br>Their Makers glory, and their justest shame;</br>Yet for the most would turn to luxurie,</br>And what they should lament, would make their game:</br>Flie then those parts, which best are undescri'd;</br>Forbear, my maiden song, to blazon wide</br>What th' Isle and Natures self doth ever strive to hide.

These two fair Isles distinct in their creation,</br>Yet one extracted from the others side,</br>Are oft made one by Loves firm combination,</br>And from this unitie are multipli'd:</br>Strange may it seem; such their condition,</br>That they are more dispread by union;</br>And two are twenty made, by being made in one.

For from these two in Loves delight agreeing,</br>Another little Isle is soon proceeding;</br>At first of unlike frame and matter being,</br>In Venus temple takes it form and breeding;</br>Till at full time the tedious prison flying,</br>It breaks all lets its ready way denying;</br>And shakes the trembling Isle with often painfull dying.

So by the Bosphor straits in Euxine seas,</br>Not farre from old Byzantum, closely stand</br>Two neighbour Islands, call'd Symplegades,</br>Which sometime seem but one combined land:</br>For often meeting on the watrie plain,</br>And parting oft, tost by the boist'rous main,</br>They now are joyn'd in one, and now disjoyn'd again.

Here oft not Lust, but sweetest Chastitie,</br>Coupled sometimes, and sometimes single, dwells;</br>Now linkt with Love, to quench Lusts tyrannie,</br>Now Phoenix-like alone in narrow cells:</br>Such Phoenix one, but one at once may be:</br>In Albions hills thee, Basilissa, thee,</br>Such onely have I seen, such shall I never see.

What Nymph was this, (said fairest Rosaleen)</br>Whom thou admirest thus above so many?</br>She, while she was, (ah!)  was the shepherds Queen;</br>Sure such a shepherds Queen was never any:</br>But (ah!)  no joy her dying heart contented,</br>Since she a deare Deers side unwilling rented;</br>Whose death she all too late, too soon, too much, repented.

Ah royall maid!  why should'st thou thus lament thee?</br>Thy little fault was but too much beleeving:</br>It is too much so much thou should'st repent thee;</br>His joyous soul at rest desires no grieving.</br>These words (vain words!)  fond comforters did lend her;</br>But (ah!)  no words, no prayers might ever bend her</br>To give an end to grief, till endlesse grief did end her.

But how should I those sorrows dare display?</br>Or how limme forth her vertues wonderment?</br>She was (ay me!  she was) the sweetest May</br>That ever flowr'd in Albions regiment.</br>Few eyes fall'n lights adore:  yet fame shall keep</br>Her name awake, when others silent sleep;</br>While men have eares to heare, eyes to look back, and weep.

And though the curres (which whelpt and nurst in Spain,</br>Learn of fell Geryon to snarle and brawl)</br>Have vow'd and strove her Virgin tombe to stain;</br>And grinne, and fome, and rage, and yelp, and bawl:</br>Yet shall our Cynthia's high-triumphing light</br>Deride their houling throats, and toothlesse spight;</br>And sail through heav'n, while they sink down in endlesse night.

So is this Islands lower region:</br>Yet ah much better is it sure then so.</br>But my poore reeds, like my condition,</br>(Low is the shepherds state, my song as low)</br>Marre what they make:  but now in yonder shade</br>Rest we, while Sunnes have longer shadows made:</br>See how our panting flocks runne to the cooler glade.
